text: Henri Gui born 1926Virtual International Authority File entry for Henri Gui accessed 10 March 2019.Surname occasionally spelt "Guy". was a French baryton- martin singer, particularly associated with the role of Pelléas in the opera by Debussy, who also sang in operetta, mainly in France but occasionally outside. ==Career== Gui sang Pelléas under Karajan, and in the same conductor's production, in Vienna in 1962, where one critic described him as “a near-perfect Pelléas - shy and withdrawn, tender in his love and moving in his suffering. He sang very well too.”Joseph Wechsberg. Austria - Karajan's 'Pelléas'. Opera, March 1962, p171-2. In May 1962 Gui appeared in the role at Glyndebourne opposite Denise Duval and Michel Roux, with his namesake Vittorio Gui conducting.Opera Annual Festival Edition - Autumn 1962 p36. At the Paris Opéra-Comique Gui sang Marcel in la Bohème in 1962,Entry for Henri Gui at the Art Lyrique Français website, accessed 11 March 2019. and Pelléas in the Debussy centenary production of Pelléas et Mélisande in December 1962.Nichols, Roger and Richard Langham Smith. Claude Debussy: Pelléas et Mélisande. Cambridge Opera Handbooks, Cambridge University Press, 1989, p162. He also sang the role at the Aix festival in 1972.Mayer, Tony. Aix-en-Provence - A mixed bag. Opera Annual Festival Autumn 1972, p70. He made his United States debut in November 1969 at the San Francisco War Memorial Opera House again as Pelléas,From San Francisco Opera archives accessed 12 March 2019. and the same year he took part in a broadcast recording for Italian Radio in Rome opposite Gabriel Bacquier as Golaud, and with Lorin Maazel conducting his first Pelléas et Mélisande.Oussenko, Sylvie. Gabriel Bacquier - le génie de l'interprétation. MJW Fédition, Paris, 2011, p. 73. Although most noted for the role of Pelléas he sang other French opera and operetta as well as Mozart: Monostatos at Aix-en-Provence in 1963 under John Pritchard.Claude Rostand. France : Aix-en-Provence: July 9–31. Opera Annual Festival - Autumn 1963, p69. and Nardo in the French premiere of Mozart’s La Finta Giardiniera, in Italian, in Strasbourg in March 1965, "the evening's best success going to Henri Gui, whose Nardo was an enchantment: he has the required light touch, and surely he is an artist for Glyndebourne in other parts than Pelléas".André Tubeuf. Strasbourg report. Opera July 1965, p509-11. In 1964 he alternated Pelléas with performances of La Fille de Madame Angot in Colmar.Annuaire de la Société historique et littéraire de Colmar. Comité d'études historiques et littéraires de Colmar. 1964, Vol 16 No.7, p147. He sang the Secretary in the French premiere of Henze's Der junge Lord in a French translation, produced and designed by Jean Pierre Ponnelle.André Tubeuf. Strasbourg report. Opera, April 1967, p318. He returned to Alsace the following season for Andrea Chenier (in French) singing Fléville and Roucher.André Tubeuf. Strasbourg report. Opera, March 1968, Vol 19 No.3, p236. At the 1967 Wexford Festival in Ireland, Gui appeared as a "superbly convincing" Mercutio in Gounod's Roméo et Juliette, and in the following year the Duc de Rothsay in Bizet's La Jolie fille de Perth.Wexford Opera archive entry for La Jolie fille de Perth accessed 11 March 2019.Wexford Opera archive entry for Roméo et Juliette accessed 11 March 2019. He sang in the premiere of Daniel-Lesur's Andrea del Sarto in Marseille, with Gabriel Bacquier in the title role and Serge Baudo conducting,Tony Mayer. France - De Musset's play, Lesur's opera (Marseilles). Opera, March 1969, Vol 20 No.3, p248. having taken part in The Mines of Sulphur in the same house the previous year.Notice de spectacle Les mines de soufre Marseille, 1968 at the BNF, accessed 13 March 2019. Back at the Opéra-Comique he sang Orphée in Milhaud's Les Malheurs d'Orphée, described as “a French baryton-martin par excellence”.Pitt, Charles. Our critics abroad – France, Paris. Opera, May 1972, p411. The same year he was seen in Platée by Rameau at the Théâtre Romain de Fourvière as Citheron. Operetta performances in the 1970s included La Fille de Madame Angot and La Veuve joyeuse (the French version of The Merry Widow - as Danilo) at the Théâtre municipal de Grenoble in 1972, La Vie parisienne in Nantes in 1975, and La Chauve-souris (the French version of Die Fledermaus) at the Opéra-théâtre d'Avignon in 1977.Henri Gui in the Archives du Spectacle accessed 14 March 2019. He appeared as Duparquet in Ciboulette in Orléans-Angers, Théâtre Municipal, in October 1975, and Hérisson de Porc-Epic in Chabrier's L'Étoile in Metz in 1979.L'Avant-scène Opéra N°242: L'Étoile à travers le monde, p79. As Henri de Valois with “warm and winning personality”, Gui took part in a complete BBC radio broadcast of Chabrier's Le Roi malgré lui recorded in Manchester in 1973, conducted by Manuel Rosenthal.Loppert, Max. On Radio: Le Serpent à Plumes (Delibes), Radio 3 , August 3, Le Roi malgré lui (Chabrier), Radio 3, August 12. Opera, November 1973, Vol.24 No.11, 1039-1042. In 1981 Radio France's included Sauguet's Le Plumet du colonel with Gui. He also appeared in the television series Airs de France as Comte Tassilo in La Comtesse Maritza (1959).Cast details for Airs de France accessed 10 March 2019. ==Discography== Gui took part in recordings of French language excerpts from Rêve de Valse by Oscar Straus in 1960, Le Pays du Sourire in 1960, and Paillasse (Silvio) conducted by Jésus Etcheverry on the Classiques Pour Tous label. As Figaro he participated in excerpts from the French version Il barbiere di Siviglia (Le Barbier de Seville) on Polaris/Véga. He was the solo singer in Le Souper - opéra pour un personnage by Marius Constant for Philips (Collection Trésors Classiques) with soloists of the ORTF chorus conducted by Marcel Couraud in 1969.Entry for Le Souper on the discogs site accessed 12 March 2019. He sang Mercutio on the 1969 EMI recording of Roméo et Juliette with the Théâtre National de l'Opéra company conducted by Alain Lombard. There were two Offenbach roles; Landry in La Chanson de Fortunio conducted by Alain Pâris (Bourg BG 2007, 1973) and Bobinet in La Vie parisienne conducted by François Rauber (French Decca 117 011, 1974). He sang the Grand Sénéchal in the opéra comique Jean de Paris by Boieldieu in 1966, published in 1991 by Gaieté lyrique : Musidisc, and appears on the album (1959) on the Orphée label. == References == Category:French operatic baritones Category:20th-century French opera singers Category:20th-century male singers
title: Henri Gui
